questiontext.text: Which technical approach did you choose for your portfolio project (Vanilla JS, Bootstrap+GSAP, or Tailwind+Vite)? Explain in detail WHY you made this choice and how it aligns with your learning goals and professional aspirations.

graderinfo.text: Look for: Clear justification, understanding of trade-offs, alignment with stated goals, technical awareness of chosen stack capabilities.

questiontext.text: What is the most important thing you learned during this project? Describe not just WHAT you learned, but HOW you learned it and why it matters for your future as a web professional.

graderinfo.text: Keywords: specific technique, problem-solving process, documentation reference, practical application, transferable skills.

questiontext.text: What was the hardest part to implement in your portfolio? Describe the challenge, the approaches you tried, and how you ultimately solved it (or what workaround you found).

graderinfo.text: Look for: Problem identification, debugging process, resource consultation, solution evaluation, learning from failure.

questiontext.text: What feature or aspect of your portfolio are you most proud of? Explain why this particular element represents your best work and what makes it special.

graderinfo.text: Look for: Technical sophistication, creative expression, problem-solving, attention to detail, personal investment.

questiontext.text: If you had two more weeks to work on your portfolio, what improvements would you prioritize? List at least 3 specific enhancements and explain why each would add value.

graderinfo.text: Look for: Self-awareness, realistic assessment, technical vision, user-centered thinking, prioritization skills.

questiontext.text:
WARNING: Provide the exact URL of your public GitHub repository for this project in the format https://github.com/username/repository. Example: https://github.com/user/repo. Incorrect, private, or missing URLs will incur a -10 point penalty.

Paste your repository URL below and briefly confirm that it contains the full source code for the deployed site.

graderinfo.text: Verify that the URL resolves to the student’s GitHub repository, that it matches the assignment requirements, and that it is publicly accessible. Apply a -10 penalty if incorrect or missing.

questiontext.text:
WARNING: Provide the exact URL of your deployed portfolio site in the format https://username.github.io/ (or the specific Netlify/Vercel domain you use). Example: https://usersubdomain.github.io/. Incorrect, offline, or missing URLs will incur a -10 point penalty.

Paste your production URL below and summarize how you verified that the deployment matches the repository version.

graderinfo.text: Visit the provided URL to ensure it is live, HTTPS, and matches the repository. Apply a -10 penalty if the deployment is missing, incorrect, or clearly outdated.

questiontext.text: What is the main trade-off when choosing a utility-first CSS framework like Tailwind over a component-based framework like Bootstrap?

answer.text: Tailwind is slower to render than Bootstrap

feedback.text: Performance depends on implementation, not the framework type.

answer.text: Tailwind requires more HTML classes but offers more design flexibility, while Bootstrap provides ready-made components with less customization

feedback.text: Correct! This captures the utility-first vs component-based trade-off.
Bootstrap 5+ works without jQuery.
Tailwind has excellent responsive design support.

questiontext.text: Build tools like Vite are only necessary for complex applications and provide no benefits for simple portfolio websites.

feedback.text: Incorrect. Build tools provide HMR, optimization, and modern JS features even for simple sites.

questiontext.text: Match each development tool with its primary purpose:

answer.text: Automatic code formatting for consistent style
JavaScript code quality and error detection

questiontext.text: Describe the responsive design strategies you implemented in your portfolio. Include specific CSS techniques (media queries, clamp(), flexbox, grid) and explain how they work together to create a fluid experience across devices.

graderinfo.text: Keywords: mobile-first, breakpoints, fluid typography, clamp(), media queries, flexbox, CSS Grid, auto-fit, minmax, container queries.

questiontext.text: What is the primary purpose of using clamp() for fluid typography in responsive web design?

answer.text: To set a fixed font size that never changes

feedback.text: Incorrect. Fixed sizes don't adapt to viewport changes.

answer.text: To create typography that scales smoothly between a minimum and maximum size based on viewport width

feedback.text: Correct! clamp(min, preferred, max) creates smooth, bounded scaling.

answer.text: To apply different fonts at different breakpoints

feedback.text: Incorrect. clamp() affects size, not font-family.

answer.text: To reduce page load time by compressing fonts

feedback.text: Incorrect. clamp() is about sizing, not compression.

questiontext.text: In a mobile-first responsive design approach, you write your base CSS for mobile devices and then use min-width media queries to progressively enhance for larger screens.

feedback.text: This statement is true. Mobile-first starts with mobile styles and enhances upward.

questiontext.text: Match each CSS layout technique with its most appropriate use case in responsive design:

answer.text: Creating responsive card grids that automatically adjust columns
One-dimensional layouts like navigation bars and button groups
Styling components based on their container size rather than viewport

info.text: CSS organization, design tokens, and modern features

questiontext.text: Are you taking advantage of a tokenized design system in your portfolio? Explain what CSS custom properties (design tokens) you defined, how they're organized, and how they benefit maintainability and consistency.

graderinfo.text: Look for: --color-*, --spacing-*, --font-*, organization in :root, theming capability, dark mode support, semantic naming.

questiontext.text: Which of the following are benefits of using CSS custom properties (design tokens) in your project? Select ALL that apply.

feedback.text: Correct! Custom properties can be redefined in different contexts.

answer.text: Single source of truth for design values

feedback.text: Correct! Changes propagate throughout the stylesheet.
Not a primary benefit. Performance depends on usage.
Correct! Consistent values across the entire project.
Correct! JS can modify custom properties at runtime.

questiontext.text: What version/level of CSS features are you using in your project? List at least 3 modern CSS features you implemented and explain why you chose them over older approaches.

graderinfo.text: Modern features: CSS Grid, Flexbox, custom properties, clamp(), container queries, :has(), :is(), scroll-snap, backdrop-filter, aspect-ratio.

questiontext.text: Are you using a barrel pattern design anywhere in your repository? If so, describe where and what benefits you obtain from this organizational pattern. If not, explain how you organized your CSS imports.

graderinfo.text: Barrel pattern: index.css importing base.css, layout.css, components.css, etc. Benefits: single import point, clear dependency order, modular organization.

questiontext.text: A well-organized CSS architecture typically starts with [[1]] (resets and variables), followed by [[2]] (grid and positioning), then [[3]] (reusable UI elements), and finally [[4]] (helper classes).
In CSS specificity, an ID selector (#header) has higher specificity than a class selector (.header), meaning ID styles will override class styles when both target the same element.

feedback.text: This is true. IDs have higher specificity than classes.

questiontext.text: Are you using JavaScript in your portfolio? If yes, describe what functionality it provides. Include specific use cases like DOM manipulation, event handling, animations, or routing.

graderinfo.text: Look for: specific functionality, event listeners, DOM manipulation methods, animation libraries (GSAP), routing logic, module organization.

questiontext.text: What is the primary benefit of using ES6 modules (import/export) instead of including multiple <script> tags?

answer.text: Modules make JavaScript code run faster

feedback.text: Not necessarily. The benefit is organizational.

answer.text: Modules provide better code organization, explicit dependencies, and avoid global namespace pollution

feedback.text: Correct! Modules encapsulate code and make dependencies explicit.

answer.text: Modules are required for all modern browsers

feedback.text: Modules are supported but not required.

answer.text: Modules reduce the total file size of JavaScript

feedback.text: File size depends on the code, not the module system.

questiontext.text: The querySelector() method returns a NodeList of all matching elements, while querySelectorAll() returns only the first matching element.

feedback.text: Incorrect. It's the opposite: querySelector returns first match, querySelectorAll returns all matches.

questiontext.text: To make a button trigger a function when clicked, you use element.[[1]]('[[2]]', functionName) to attach the event handler.

Do you follow any accessibility strategy in your portfolio? Describe specific accessibility features you implemented, such as color contrast, keyboard navigation, alt text, ARIA attributes, or reduced motion support.

graderinfo.text: Keywords: WCAG, color contrast 4.5:1, prefers-reduced-motion, alt text, keyboard focus, skip links, semantic HTML, ARIA roles.

questiontext.text: Why would you say your website is semantic? Explain what semantic HTML elements you used and why using semantic markup is better than using only <div> and <span> elements.

graderinfo.text: Semantic elements: header, nav, main, article, section, aside, footer. Benefits: accessibility, SEO, maintainability, screen reader support, document outline.

questiontext.text: Which of the following HTML5 elements are considered semantic? Select ALL that apply.

feedback.text: Correct! article represents self-contained content.
Incorrect. div is a generic container with no semantic meaning.
Correct! nav represents navigation links.
Incorrect. span is a generic inline container.
Correct! main represents the main content area.
Correct! footer represents footer content.
Correct! section represents a thematic grouping.

questiontext.text: To respect users who prefer reduced motion, CSS provides the @media (prefers-[[1]]: [[2]]) query, which should be used to [[3]] animations for accessibility.
What is the minimum color contrast ratio required by WCAG AA standards for normal body text?

feedback.text: Too low. This doesn't meet accessibility standards.
This is the ratio for large text, not body text.
Correct! WCAG AA requires 4.5:1 for normal text.
This is WCAG AAA level, stricter than required.

questiontext.text: Where has your project been deployed? Name the web server/hosting platform and the domain/URL. Explain any deployment configuration you needed to set up (e.g., GitHub Pages settings, build scripts, custom domain).

graderinfo.text: Expected: GitHub Pages, Netlify, Vercel, or similar. URL should be HTTPS. Configuration details show understanding of deployment process.

questiontext.text: Are you fetching media or resources from any CDN? If so, which ones and for what purpose? What benefits do you obtain from using CDNs instead of self-hosting these resources?

graderinfo.text: CDN benefits: faster loading (geographic distribution), caching, reduced server load, automatic optimization. Common CDNs: cdnjs, unpkg, jsDelivr, ImageKit, Cloudinary.

questiontext.text: Why is HTTPS essential for modern web deployment, even for static portfolio sites?

answer.text: It makes the website load faster

feedback.text: Speed depends on many factors, not primarily HTTPS.

answer.text: It encrypts data transmission, builds user trust, and is required for many modern web features

feedback.text: Correct! HTTPS provides security, trust, and enables features like Service Workers.

answer.text: It is only needed for e-commerce websites

feedback.text: Incorrect. HTTPS is a modern standard for all websites.

answer.text: It prevents all forms of hacking

feedback.text: HTTPS encrypts transmission but doesn't prevent all security issues.

questiontext.text: GitHub Pages automatically provides HTTPS for custom domains and requires no additional configuration to enable secure connections.

feedback.text: This is true. GitHub Pages handles HTTPS automatically.

questiontext.text: What do you think of Git after using it throughout this course? What aspects do you appreciate most? What challenges did you encounter, and how did you overcome them?

graderinfo.text: Positive aspects: version history, branching, collaboration, rollback capability. Challenges: merge conflicts, command complexity, understanding staging area.

questiontext.text: Can you explain what GitHub does in relation to Git? How are they different, and how do they work together in your development workflow?

graderinfo.text: Git: distributed version control system (local). GitHub: cloud hosting platform for Git repositories, adds collaboration features (issues, PRs, Actions), social coding.

questiontext.text: Match each Git concept with its correct description:

answer.text: A snapshot of your project at a specific point in time
An independent line of development that can diverge from the main codebase
A GitHub feature to propose and review changes before merging

questiontext.text: What is the purpose of creating a Git tag like v1.0.0 for your portfolio submission?

feedback.text: Tags don't automatically deploy; they mark versions.

answer.text: To mark a specific point in history as a release version for easy reference

feedback.text: Correct! Tags create permanent references to specific commits.
Incorrect. Tags don't affect commit history.
Incorrect. Tags and branches serve different purposes.

questiontext.text: Are you using any API in your project? If yes, describe which APIs and their purpose. More broadly, explain why APIs are important in the modern web ecosystem.

graderinfo.text: APIs mentioned: DOM API, Fetch API, third-party APIs. Importance: interoperability, data exchange, service integration, microservices architecture, platform capabilities.

questiontext.text: What additions or features would you consider to make your site align with Web 3.0 concepts? Discuss at least two Web 3.0 characteristics and how they could enhance your portfolio.

graderinfo.text: Web 3.0: semantic web, machine-readable data, decentralization, blockchain, AI integration, personalization, structured data (JSON-LD, Schema.org).

questiontext.text: Match each web evolution stage with its primary characteristics:

answer.text: Static content, read-only pages, basic hyperlinks between documents
User-generated content, social media, interactive web applications
Semantic web, AI agents, decentralization, machine-readable data

questiontext.text: An API (Application Programming [[1]]) allows different software applications to [[2]] with each other by defining a set of [[3]].

Is your portfolio PWA-ready (Progressive Web App)? Describe what PWA features you implemented (manifest.json, service workers, offline capability) or explain what would be needed to make it PWA-ready.

graderinfo.text: PWA requirements: manifest.json, service worker, HTTPS, responsive design, app-like experience. Benefits: installable, offline-capable, push notifications.

questiontext.text: How would you describe the three main design principles or visual directions of your portfolio? Explain the key aesthetic choices (colors, typography, layout patterns) and how they support your personal brand.

graderinfo.text: Look for: coherent visual system, intentional choices, brand alignment, user experience consideration, design trend implementation.

questiontext.text: What differences do you find between web design and traditional graphic design? Relate your answer specifically to your portfolio project, discussing how web-specific constraints (responsiveness, interactivity, performance) influenced your design decisions.

graderinfo.text: Differences: dynamic vs static, responsive vs fixed, interactive vs passive, performance constraints, accessibility requirements, multi-device consideration, code implementation.

questiontext.text: Which modern web design trends did you implement in your portfolio? Select ALL that apply to your project.

feedback.text: Using backdrop-filter: blur() for glass effects.
Theme switching with CSS custom properties.
Different scroll speeds for depth effect.
Subtle animations on user actions.
Modern color transitions.
Section-by-section navigation.

questiontext.text: What AI tools (if any) did you use during your portfolio development? Be specific about which tools (GitHub Copilot, ChatGPT, Claude, Cursor, etc.) and for what purposes (planning, coding, debugging, content).

graderinfo.text: Look for: honest disclosure, specific use cases, understanding of AI capabilities and limitations.

questiontext.text: Have you credited AI assistance in your project documentation? Describe how you documented AI usage in your README and plan files. Why is transparent AI disclosure important in academic and professional contexts?

graderinfo.text: Expected: docs/plan1.md, plan2.md files, README section on AI usage, two-phase workflow (planning then implementation), ethical considerations.

questiontext.text: How has using AI assistants (if at all) enhanced or affected your learning during this project? Discuss both positive impacts and potential drawbacks you experienced.

graderinfo.text: Positive: faster problem-solving, exposure to patterns, explanations. Negative: dependency risk, reduced deep learning, need for verification.

questiontext.text: According to the course methodology, when using AI coding assistants, you should always request a development plan (Phase 1) and document it before proceeding with implementation (Phase 2).

feedback.text: This is true. Planning before implementation is required for AI-assisted development in this course.

questiontext.text: The Web Atelier methodology emphasizes "learning by doing, with theory, practice, and shared reflection." How did this project embody this approach? Reflect on how theory, hands-on practice, and reflection contributed to your learning.

graderinfo.text: Connection to: lesson materials (theory), implementation (practice), documentation and exam (reflection), peer learning, professor support.

questiontext.text: This project aimed to create a "fishing net, not catch a single fish" - a reusable template rather than a one-time portfolio. How well did you achieve this goal? What makes your template easily customizable for future projects?

graderinfo.text: Look for: CSS custom properties for theming, modular structure, documentation, clear naming conventions, separation of content and presentation.

questiontext.text: Which professional web development standards did you implement in your portfolio? Select ALL that apply.

feedback.text: Using meaningful HTML elements.

answer.text: Git version control with meaningful commits

feedback.text: Professional development workflow.
Consistent code style.
Project documentation.
Secure hosting.
Multi-device compatibility.
Fast loading times.
